newsitem.title: USA: Travolta, Cruise share honors at U.S. box office.
newsitem.headline: Travolta, Cruise share honors at U.S. box office.

text.p: In a weekend that saw no new national releases at the box office, the top spot was shared by two of Hollywood's most bankable stars, John Travolta with "Michael" and Tom Cruise with "Jerry Maguire," according to studio estimates released on Sunday.

Each movie grossed an estimated $12.5 million during the Friday-to-Sunday period. Rising two places to third was the emsemble slasher picture "Scream," while "101 Dalmatians" and "One Fine Day" took fourth and fifth, respectively.
The one new entry to the top 10 was "Ghosts of Mississippi" at seventh place.

The critically savaged movie about the murder of civil rights activist Medgar Evers widened to 1,268 screens from 21 the weekend, before when it was 29th. The Rob Reiner-directed picture is released by Columbia Pictures, a unit of Sony Corp.

Both "Michael" and "Jerry Maguire" suffered relatively tiny drops from the weekend before, when "Michael" opened in first with $17.4 million. "Michael" fell 28 percent, while "Jerry Maguire" slipped 11 percent, the smallest decline in the top 10.
"Michael," which is released by New Line Cinema, a unit of Time Warner Inc., has earned $53.6 million since opening on Christmas Day.

"Jerry Maguire" is now up to $83.4 million since it opened in first during the Dec. 13-15 weekend. The romantic comedy starring Cruise as an aggressive sports agent is released by Sony's TriStar Pictures banner.
"Scream," directed by Wes Craven and starring Drew Barrymore, Neve Campbell and Courteney Cox, has emerged as one of the surprise hits of the holiday period.
Its gross rose 10 percent for the weekend to $10 million, giving it a 17-day total of $39.1 million. The movie is released by Miramax Films, a unit of Walt Disney Co..
"Scream" averaged $5,777 from 1,731 screens, the highest average in the top 10. By contrast, "Michael" averaged $5,731 and "Jerry Maguire" $4,939, both respectable tallies.
These averages were left in the dust, however, by several highly praised movies playing in limited release.
With a weekend gross of $1.1 million, "Evita" averaged $50,000 from 22 screens and "The People Vs. Larry Flynt" earned $600,000 from 16 screens, giving it an average of $37,500.
"Evita" is released by Disney, while "Flynt" is handled by Columbia Pictures.
Disney's "101 Dalmatians" slipped a notch to fourth with $7.4 million. Its 40-day total is $121.8 million.
"One Fine Day," an under-performing romantic comedy starring Michelle Pfeiffer and George Clooney, gained one place to fifth with $6.8 million. Its 17-day total is $34.8 million.
The movie is released by 20th Century Fox, a unit of News Corp.
